questions.text: A preterm baby in the neonatal intensive care unit is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). She is found to have stage 2 ROP in zone I with no plus disease.  What is the recommended treatment for this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended treatment for ROP stage 2 in zone I (categorized as type I/low-risk ROP) is careful observation and follow-up.

Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants with low birth weight, with a typical history of exposure to oxygen in high concentrations leading to bilateral proliferative retinopathy. 

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1- demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3- ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4- subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- total retinal detachment
  • 'Plus' disease is characterized by dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels in at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. It signifies the progression of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from disc to the fovea, with the disc as the center. (as shown in the image)
Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal ora serrata.
Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

These zones are shown in the image below:

 

Treatment is based on guidelines set by the early treatment of retinopathy of prematurity trial (ETROP).

Type 1: Treatment within 72 hours (High risk)

  • Any ROP + plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP in zone I
  • Stage 2/3 in zone II + plus disease.

Type 2: Observation (Low risk)

  • Stage 1/2 in zone I only and no plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP within zone II and no plus disease.

This can be summarized in the table below:

Zone II - without plus disease   Observation  Observation
Zone II- with plus disease   Treatment Treatment

 

ROP of any stage in any zone, if associated with 'plus' disease, should receive treatment urgently.

Treatment includes laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina, anti-VEGF medication (bevacizumab), and pars plana vitrectomy for advanced disease. The high-risk patients requiring treatment should receive it within 72 hours.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency department after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

questions.text: A  50-year-old male patient presents with sudden onset chest pain. On examination his pulses are weak and his blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. Contrast-enhanced CT shows a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of sudden onset chest pain along with feeble pulses and low blood pressure is suggestive of a large vessel disorder. This can be confirmed by contrast-enhanced CT which shows a thoracic aortic aneurysmal rupture.  Polyarteritis nodosa is not associated with this condition.

Thoracic aortic aneurysm refers to the dilatation of the thoracic aorta which can occur in any part. It can be a true aneurysm involving all three layers of the vessel or a false aneurysm, involving only the outer adventitial layer, with blood escaping through the intima. Circumferential involvement is referred to as a fusiform aneurysm while it is called a saccular aneurysm if only part of the circumference is involved.

The most common cause is atherosclerosis, but this pathology is also closely associated with several connective tissue disorders such as:

  • Marfan's syndrome
  • Tertiary syphilis (syphilitic aortitis)
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta

These aneurysms are often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, but if they progressively enlarge, it can lead to symptoms suggestive of compression of the surrounding tissue (dysphagia, dyspnea, hoarseness of the voice, etc.). Aneurysm of the aortic root can cause dilatation of the aortic valve annulus and result in aortic regurgitation. Rupture can occur into the pericardium or the left pleural space, producing hypotension and dyspnea.

The diagnosis can be made with the help of a contrast-enhanced CT or MRI scan. Indications for surgery include any symptomatic aneurysm, rupture, progressive aortic valve insufficiency, symptomatic Marfan's related aneurysms of 4.5-5 cm, and descending symptomatic aneurysms >6 cm. Surgery can also be considered if the aneurysmal diameter is increasing at >1 cm per year. 

Incorrect option- Polyarteritis nodosa is a type of vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels of the kidneys and other viscera. It does not involve the pulmonary vasculature or large vessels like the aorta.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe pain in the abdomen. His mother gives a history of several such repeated episodes of pain in the abdomen, bones, and distal ends of the digits in the past 2 years. He suffered an autosplenectomy the previous year during a similar painful episode. Laboratory findings show unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and significant reticulocytosis. Which of the following is correct regarding his disease?

choices.text: Caused by a point mutation in the alpha globin gene
Heterozygous trait can protect against dengue
Howell Jolly bodies seen on peripheral smear

questions.solution:
The child presents with a history of multiple pain crises, splenectomy, and laboratory findings of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normocytic anemia. These features point to a diagnosis of sickle cell anemia. Howell Jolly bodies are seen in the peripheral smear of a patient with sickle cell disease.

The below image shows Howell-Jolly bodies:

Sickle cell anemia is an inherited (autosomal recessive) disorder of hemoglobin molecules in which deoxygenated molecules undergo distortion, leading to the classic occlusive crises, hemolytic anemia, and tissue damage. This disease is the result of a point mutation in the beta-globin gene which results in a glutamate residue being replaced by a valine residue. The patients who are homozygous for this mutation present with the above-mentioned features. Those who are heterozygous, are said to have sickle cell trait. This trait can provide a degree of protection against falciparum malaria. This could be because of increases in oxidant stress which can damage the membranes of cells infected by the organism.

Sickle cell disease results in hemolytic anemia with reticulocytosis, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and irreversible sickled red blood cells. These sickle cells can obstruct vessels and cause classic pain crises. These episodes can occur in any part of the body, commonly seen in the abdomen, bones, and chest. Repeated episodes of splenic artery vaso-occlusion can result in a splenic sequestration crises. At this stage it becomes necessary to remove the spleen. This leaves the child even more vulnerable to infections. Appropriate post-splenectomy antibiotic prophylaxis and vaccination should be carried out. In patients who have undergone splenectomy, the peripheral smear can show Howell Jolly bodies, which are basophilic nuclear remnants that would normally be removed by the spleen.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis and sickling tests.

questions.text: Which of the following factors related to platelet aggregation is absent in Glanzmann's thrombasthenia?
questions.solution:
The Gp IIb/IIIa receptor is absent in Glanzmann's thrombasthenia.

Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disorder of platelet aggregation in which the Gp IIb/IIIa receptor is absent.

During platelet plug formation, the initial stimulus is vessel injury. The site of injury reveals the von Willebrand factor, which then binds to the platelets via the Gp Ib receptors. This step leads to the activation of platelets with the release of substances that promote further platelet aggregation and inhibit anticoagulation. Gp IIb/IIIa receptors are the most abundant receptors on the platelet surface, which also get activated and help to bring about platelet-platelet interaction by binding them with a molecule of fibrinogen as shown in the diagram below.

Hence, the absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors in Glanzmann's thrombasthenia will allow only minimal platelet adhesion to the site of vessel injury but will not allow the platelet plug to form. This leads to various bleeding manifestations such as gum bleeding, epistaxis, easy bruisability, etc.

Laboratory findings include prolonged bleeding time, normal PT/aPTT, normal platelet count, and normal platelet morphology. Specific platelet aggregation tests with collagen, ADP, etc. will fail to bring about platelet aggregation, but the ristocetin cofactor assay will be normal. This is because the ristocetin cofactor assay tests the integrity of the Gp Ib binding to von Willebrand factor. This will be normal in patients with Glanzmann's. So, this test can be used to differentiate it from Bernaner Soulier syndrome (absence of Gp Ib).

Treatment for this disorder depends on the severity of the bleed. Minor mucosal bleeds can be managed with antifibrinolytics such as ε-aminocaproic acid or tranexamic acid. Desmopressin is used in mild bleeds by releasing von Willebrand factor, factor VIII and by activating platelets further. Severe bleeds are usually treated with platelet transfusions. Leukodepletion can help to prevent alloimmunization in such patients who may require these transfusions often.

questions.text: The cutaneous lymphoma shown in the image below presents with patches and plaques, most commonly on the back. Histological examination shows the classic Pautrier abscess. This condition commonly progresses to a particular syndrome. Which of the following is not a feature of that syndrome?
questions.solution:
The image shown above with cutaneous patches and plaques and the characteristic Pautrier microabscesses is suggestive of a diagnosis of mycosis fungoides. Mycosis fungoides can progress to a syndrome called Sezary syndrome. Neutrophilic microabscesses are not one of the features of this syndrome.

Sezary syndrome is defined by the following clinical triad:

  • Erythroderma
  • Peripheral lymphadenopathy
  • Atypical circulating mononuclear cells

Sezary syndrome is most often seen as a progression of mycosis fungoides (MF). MF is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It is more common in middle-aged men and people with darker skin. MF may present as dermatitis or eczema for a few years before progressing to the classical presentation of patches and plaques as shown in the image above. The most common sites involved are the trunk, limbs, breasts, and buttocks. The lesions may present with pruritus or be asymptomatic. As it progresses, the patient may develop, ulceration and pain or even widespread erythroderma. The gradual progression to Sezary syndrome with erythroderma and lymphadenopathy may be accompanied by the typical 'B' symptoms of fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Important investigations to consider are cutaneous and lymph node biopsies (showing the Pautrier abscess, which is a lymphocytic microabscess) and blood samples to count the Sezary cells (atypical mononuclear tumor cells). Treatment for both MF and Sezary syndrome depends upon the severity of the disease. Topical steroid therapy, phototherapy, and skin-directed radiotherapy can be tried as a first-line attempt. Advanced disease can be treated with methotrexate, interferons, chemotherapy, etc.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with dizziness and palpitations since 3 days. On examination, she has an irregularly irregular pulse, with ECG findings as shown below. If she were to undergo surgical ablation to treat this condition, which part of the myocardium should be targeted?

choices.text: Across the bicuspid annulus, from the left atrium to  free wall of the ventricle
From the AV node towards the tricuspid annulus
Left atrial regions around the pulmonary veins

questions.solution:
The given history and the ECG findings of an irregularly irregular rhythm, absent p waves, and narrow QRS complexes are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. If she were to undergo surgical ablation to treat this condition, the left atrial regions around the pulmonary veins should be targeted.

The triggering foci for atrial fibrillation most commonly originate from the left atrial tissue, near the openings of the pulmonary veins. When medical management is unsuccessful or if quicker results are desired, cardiac ablation can be carried out. Targeting this region will produce the best results.

Atrial fibrillation refers to an irregular atrial activation, with the absence of atrial contraction. Ventricular contraction is irregular, depending on the atrioventricular nodal conduction rate. Atrial fibrillation is the most common cardiac arrhythmia, and most patients are above the age of 60 years. Patients present with palpitations, dizziness, syncopal episodes, etc. On examination, they are found to have irregularly irregular pulses and, in severe cases, even cardiovascular collapse and heart failure.

ECG shows an increased rate and irregular rhythm with the absence of p waves. The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to determine a patient's risk of developing stroke, and if the score is >2, the patient is recommended to start oral anticoagulation therapy. Beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are most commonly used to treat atrial fibrillation, and they help to control the ventricular rate and improve symptoms. 

Obesity, hypertension, alcohol abuse, and sleep apnea are known risk factors and should be controlled in order to reduce the incidence of these episodes.

Other options:

Option A: In Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, the most common accessory pathway is found across the bicuspid annulus, from the left atrium to the free wall of the left ventricle; the other common accessory pathways are the posteroseptal and anteroseptal accessory pathways.

Option B: AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia circuits are most commonly found along the path from the AV node to the tricuspid valve annulus.

Option C: Atrial flutter most commonly originates around the cavotricuspid isthmus, and ablation of this area can resolve the condition in most cases.

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A young man falls on an outstretched hand and develops a fracture as shown in the X-ray below.  Which of the following screws is commonly used to treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray and the history of falls on the outstretched hands suggest the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture. Herbert screw is commonly used to treat this fracture.

Herbert screw is a cannulated variable pitch screw, which is used to fix unstable or displaced fractures of small articular bones such as the scaphoid. This screw helps in quick healing by providing compression at the fracture site and early return to normal activities. The advantage of cannulated screws is that we can use a guidewire under videofluoroscopy to assist in the accurate placement of the screw during surgery.

Scaphoid fractures occur most commonly after a fall on an outstretched hand. The waist of the scaphoid is the most common site of fracture. Initial x-rays are done in anteroposterior, lateral, and oblique views. Even if the x-rays appear normal, if there is clinical suspicion, a glass holding cast should be applied for 2 weeks followed by repeat imaging.

Management depends upon the type of fracture. If the scaphoid tubercle is fractured, the patient is given a glass-holding cast for 4-6 weeks. In case of undisplaced waist fractures, most people will recover with a cast in place for 6-8 weeks. Percutaneous screw fixation with the Herbert screw can be offered to those with displaced or undisplaced fractures of the waist when the patient does not want to undergo prolonged cast immobilization, or if they wish to return to work/daily activities sooner. Reducing and fixing displaced fractures also reduces the risk of non-union.

The most common complications include nonunion, avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the proximal fracture segment, and osteoarthritis. 

Herbert screw is shown below:

 

Other options:

Option A: Cannulated cancellous screws are commonly used to treat fractures of the neck of the femur.

Option B: The interference screw is a biodegradable screw used during anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction. This screw is made of polymers that increase its strength so as to improve cortical bone formation at the site as well as to ensure that the tibial tunnel is not too wide during the insertion of the newly reconstructed ligament.

Option D: Pedicle screws are used in spinal fusion surgery to provide added strength and support. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws, which prevent their movement and allow the bone to heal. They are also used in the correction of scoliosis.

questions.text:
What is the mechanism of action of the poison obtained from the seeds shown in the image below?

VAMP- Vesicle-associated membrane protein

GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid

ACh- Acetylcholine

choices.text: Blocking peripheral and central ACh receptors
Blocking glycine receptors in the ventral horn

questions.solution:
The seeds of Strychnos nux vomica are shown in the given image. The poison obtained from these seeds is strychnine. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem.

Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that acts at the postsynaptic membranes of ventral horn motor neurons. Hence, the blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features. These include:

  • Tonic-clonic seizures
  • Opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension)
  • Risus sardonicus
  • Other less common postures that can be seen are emprosthotonus (body bent forward as if bowing) and pleurosthotonus (body bent sideward). 

Strychnos nux vomica seeds are toxic only when chewed/ crushed prior to swallowing. Intact seeds, if swallowed, will not result in any further symptoms. Treatment involves an initial stomach wash and the use of activated charcoal to absorb the ingested poison. The patient should be treated with benzodiazepines or barbiturates to control seizures, and they should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions.

Other options: 

Option (A)- Blocking peripheral postsynaptic ACh receptors can be seen in curare poisoning. It can cause progressive flaccid paralysis, ultimately leading to respiratory failure. It was used as an arrow poison during wars in the past.

Option (B)- Blocking peripheral and central ACh receptors can be seen in datura poisoning. It acts by competitive antagonism. All the parts of the datura plant are poisonous. It shows predominantly peripheral anticholinergic effects like flushed face, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils, delirium, urinary retention, etc. with central effects like psychosis and delirium.

Option (C)- VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein) cleavage in GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) neurons at the ventral horn of the spinal cord, is the mechanism of action of toxins in tetanus infections. VAMP is normally responsible for the release of GABA, hence VAMP cleavage results in unopposed muscular contractions. The resulting clinical features are very similar to that of strychnine poisoning. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of somatic delusion?
questions.solution:
Othello Syndrome is not a type of somatic delusion.

It is a type of delusional jealousy, marked by suspecting a faithful partner of infidelity.

Somatic delusion is diagnosed when the central themes of the delusional beliefs are of a hypochondriacal or somatic nature, where the person believes there is something medically, physically or biologically wrong with them.

It includes the following:

  • Concerns about infestation in delusional parasitosis
  • Preoccupation with body features in dysmorphic delusions
  • Delusional concerns about body odour, referred to as bromosis

questions.text: Administration of O2 has maximum benefit in:
questions.solution:
Administration of oxygen has maximum benefit in hypoxic hypoxia.

Hypoxic hypoxia refers to a condition in which there is low atmospheric Po2, leading to low arterial Po2. Hence, supplemental O2 can be very beneficial when the cause of hypoxia is due to limited oxygen availability.

Administration of oxygen-rich gas has limited value in anemic, histotoxic, and stagnant hypoxia because:

Anemic hypoxia- Oxygen delivery is not beneficial because despite increasing the exogenous oxygen delivery, an anemic person will not have the capacity to carry more oxygen due to the hemoglobin/ red blood cell deficit in anemia.

Histotoxic hypoxia- The most common example is cyanide poisoning. Cyanide inhibits important enzymes in the oxidative phosphorylation process, which is essential to the survival of our cells. Additional oxygen supplementation will not be able to overcome this inhibition, and so it will have limited benefit. Hyperbaric oxygen may be helpful to some extent.

Stagnant hypoxia- Stagnant hypoxia refers to ischemic hypoxia that results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock. In such conditions, administering intravenous fluids can improve the patient's condition because it is the circulation that is affected. If the shock is prolonged it can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which can be treated with positive pressure ventilation and not simply by increasing oxygen administration.

questions.text: A  young man is brought unconscious to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. On examination,  his left pupil is dilated with a normal right pupil. He also has a positive Babinski's sign in the left foot. Identify the most likely site of brain herniation leading to this presentation.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a unilateral pupillary dilatation with signs of ipsilateral upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy [Babinski's sign positive], is suggestive of Kernohan's notch phenomenon. This is likely due to herniation of the part labeled (3) in the above image i.e. uncal herniation.

Herniation of the uncus (anterior medial temporal gyrus) from the supratentorial to the infratentorial region results in compression of the ipsilateral third cranial nerve. This results in pupillary dilatation of the same side (parasympathetic fibers are present superficially in the nerve). As the herniation progresses, the contralateral midbrain and thus the contralateral cerebral peduncle gets compressed against the tentorial edge on that side. This presents as a UMN palsy of the same side as the uncal herniation with a positive Babinski's sign. Normally the side opposite the herniation would be expected to show hemiparesis. 

Subfalcine herniation (labeled 1) refers to the herniation of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri. It presents initially with headache. Once it compresses the ipsilateral anterior cerebral artery it can result in contralateral lower limb weakness. This type of herniation does not involve the pupillary functions.

Central herniation/central transtentorial herniation(labeled 4) would present with the initial signs of mitotic pupils and drowsiness due to the downward displacement of the thalamic structures through the tentorial opening, resulting in compression of the upper midbrain. It can later progress to damage the pons and medulla as well.

Foraminal herniation (labeled 2) refers to the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This results in early compression of the medulla, leading to respiratory arrest and death.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of episodic flushing. She also complains of diarrhea, which is watery, non-bloody, explosive, and accompanied by abdominal cramping. Further evaluation reveals a tumor in the ileum with the histopathology shown below.  Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: 5- HIAA is used for lab diagnosis
Pellagra can develop due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with symptoms of abdominal cramping, explosive diarrhea, and episodic flushing, along with the characteristic histopathological findings (stippled chromatin pattern, without mitotic activity or necrosis) points to the diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome. The statement- 'anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are present' is untrue about this condition.

Carcinoid syndrome is the result of a carcinoid tumor that secretes excessive amounts of serotonin, which is a product of the amino acid tryptophan. Serotonin is ultimately metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA (5-hydroxy indole acetic acid). 

The following tests can be used in the diagnosis of carcinoid tumors:

  • Urinary excretion of 5-HIAA and serotonin
  • Serum chromogranin concentration
  • Blood serotonin concentration
  • Plasma 5-HIAA concentration
  • Tumor localization with CT, MRI, somatostatin receptor imaging, and endoscopic biopsy

In carcinoid syndrome, elevated levels of serotonin stimulate fibroblast growth and fibrogenesis, which leads to the development of cardiac valvular lesions. These lesions most often affect the right side of the heart because the inactivation of humoral substances by the lung protects the left heart. In a few cases, the left side of the heart may be affected (in patients with right-to-left shunt, as in patent foramen ovale).

Alterations in tryptophan metabolism are seen in all patients with over 70% of dietary tryptophan converted to serotonin. Some tumors also produce histamine, kallikrein, prostaglandins, and tachykinins.

These features of serotonin result in the following symptoms that are found often in carcinoid syndrome-

  • Episodic flushing
  • Diarrhea - explosive, non-bloody, and accompanied by abdominal cramping
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cardiac valvular lesions - commonly involve the right side because the left heart is protected by the humoral inactivation of substances by the lungs
  • Pellagra- because of shunting of most of the dietary tryptophan to serotonin synthesis. (4 D's: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, death)
  • Muscle wasting due to poor protein synthesis
  • Mesenteric and retroperitoneal fibrosis

Treatment:

  • Somatostatin analog therapy
  • Antidiarrheal therapy
  • Surgical excision

Incorrect option: 

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are used to diagnose celiac disease. Celiac disease is a malabsorptive disorder that can present in early childhood with diarrhea. This usually occurs after introducing cereals into the child's diet. The symptoms usually disappear over a few years and may or may not re-appear in adulthood. The diagnosis is made by testing for autoantibodies (such as anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-gliadin) and by performing a small intestine biopsy, which can show flattening of the villi.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of the condition marked as '1' in the image below?

choices.text: Scalp ecchymoses are a common finding
20% of the cases result in mortality

questions.solution:
The area marked '1' represents a caput succedaneum. Scalp ecchymoses are a feature of this condition.

Caput succedaneum is an ill-defined swelling over the scalp that is caused by excessive pressure to the neonatal head by the cervix and pelvic walls during vaginal delivery. It presents as a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It is present at the time of delivery. It does not require any treatment and disappears within 1 week of life.

Other swellings associated with the neonatal skull include:

Cephalhematoma- It is a well-defined fluid-filled swelling that is contained within suture lines and does not cross them. It is not present at the time of birth and usually develops after a few hours/one day. This swelling is usually filled with blood. Hence, the resulting hemolysis leads to the development of jaundice with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonate. Some babies may require phototherapy in severe cases. It resolves within 2 weeks to a few months.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage- It can have a mortality of over 20%. It is an accumulation of blood underneath the aponeurosis of the scalp (galea aponeurotica). This is also a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It usually occurs due to rupture of emissary veins, and is associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. A timely diagnosis is essential to prevent hypovolemic shock and death of the neonate.

Epidural hemorrhage - It is an accumulation of blood between the dura mater and the inner surface of the skull. It results from prolonged labor or a fetal head disproportionate to the size of the mother's birth canal. It usually resolves without any complications.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with chickenpox calls his family doctor and asks how long he should isolate to prevent the infection from spreading to his family. What should the physician tell him?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir
Until all the lesions are crusted

questions.solution:
The physician should tell the man that he must isolate himself from his family until all of his skin lesions are crusted. This will help to prevent the transmission of the virus to his family members. Isolation is an important method to prevent the further spread of chickenpox as the secondary attack rates in household contacts are very high (up to 90%). The individual remains infective from approximately 48 hours before the appearance of the rash, during the time of vesicle formation (4-5 days), and till the point where all the lesions have crusted over. 

Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It spreads via droplet infection during personal contact and enters through the respiratory system or the conjunctiva. The course of chickenpox can be divided into 2 stages-

  • Pre-eruptive The pre-eruptive stage includes the fever and viral prodrome, which lasts for 2-3 days until the rash begins to appear
  • The eruptive stage begins with the appearance of the rash. It usually appears first on the trunk, followed by the limbs and face. The rash quickly goes through the various stages (pleomorphism)-macule, papule, vesicle, and finally scab. The vesicle stage has classically been said to have a "dew-drop" appearance. Complications such as cerebellar ataxia, pneumonia, and encephalitis are uncommon but can be seen in some adults and immunocompromised patients. 

The usual control methods include notifying regarding a new case, isolation, and disinfection. Antiviral therapy like acyclovir can prevent systemic disease, especially in immunosuppressed patients. Exposed patients who are immunocompromised may receive the varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG), within 72 hours of exposure to a chickenpox patient. The immunoglobulin must be administered immediately as it has no effect once the disease is established. 

Other options:

Option A: Fever and malaise may subside during the eruptive (vesicle formation) stage, but the patient remains contagious at this point.

Option B: It is unnecessary to isolate until all the lesions have disappeared because the patient is not at risk of transmitting the virus once the lesions have crusted.

Option C: Acyclovir is recommended in adults and children if started within 24 hours of disease onset. However, in some patients with mild illness, conservative management is sufficient.  Regardless of the treatment taken, patients are recommended to follow the same isolation guidelines.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of staring spells in school. She is diagnosed with absence seizures. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for ethosuximide, a drug commonly used for this condition?

GABA: gamma-Aminobutyric acid

choices.text: Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels

questions.solution:
Ethosuximide is commonly used in children suffering from absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is the inhibition of T-type calcium channels.

Absence seizures originate in the thalamus and produce the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. This pattern is produced due to the intrinsic properties of the low threshold T-type calcium channels of the thalamus. These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Valproate acts by blocking both calcium and sodium channels. It is effective in the treatment of absence, myoclonic, focal, and tonic-clonic seizures.

Option B: Vigabatrin inhibits GABA transaminase and thus increases GABA concentration in the brain. It is the drug of choice for infantile spasms seen in tuberous sclerosis.

Option C: Benzodiazepines enhance GABA-mediated synaptic inhibition. Benzodiazepines act at GABAA receptors and increase the frequency, but not duration, of openings at GABA-activated Cl− channels

questions.text: A  26-year-old male patient presents with painful ulcers on his penis with the classical "kissing ulcer" appearance. He also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.  Which of the following will be found on microscopy of the smear from these lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender genital ulcers with the "kissing ulcer" appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy most likely has a diagnosis of chancroid. The classical "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance will be found on microscopy of the smear from these lesions, as shown below:

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings, "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance.

Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g oral) or ceftriaxone (250mg intramuscular).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform and treat their sexual partners from the last 3 months.

Other options:

(B) Spirochetes are seen on dark field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis can be confirmed by specific treponemal tests such as fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS), Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test (TPHA), and the enzyme immunoassay (EIA). Treatment is with parental penicillin G, irrespective of the stage of the disease. Dose and duration depend on the clinical stage and presentation. In the case of penicillin hypersensitivity, regimens based on doxycycline, erythromycin, tetracycline, and chloramphenicol are used for treatment.

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes are shown below:


(C) Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Management is with a course of azithromycin.

(D) Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base with painful inguinal lymph nodes. The diagnosis can be made with an initial Tzanck smear by deroofing the vesicles and taking a swab. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing can be used to confirm this diagnosis. The first-line drug used to treat herpes genitalis is oral aciclovir.

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with small bumps on the cheeks and nasolabial folds as shown in the image below. She is a known case of seizure disorder on medication. On examination, there is a hypopigmented oval patch on the lower back. What is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of facial angiofibromas, seizures, and a hypomelanotic oval patch on the back suggests tuberous sclerosis (TS). It has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance mode. The mutations involve the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis is diagnosed when at least two major or one major plus two minor features are present.

  • Major features: 
    • Cortical dysplasias (including tubers and cerebral white matter migration lines)
    • Subependymal nodules
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
    • Facial angiofibromas (≥3) or forehead plaque
    • Ungual fibromas (≥2)
    • Hypomelanotic macules (≥3, ≥5 mm in diameter)
    • Shagreen patch
    • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Minor features: 
    • Dental enamel pits (>3)
    • Intraoral fibromas (≥2)
    • Retinal achromic patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
    • Nonrenal hamartomas
    • Multiple renal cysts

The CT image given below shows subependymal nodules seen in TS.

Note: When these lesions are calcified, they project into the ventricular cavity having a candle-drip appearance.


Children are usually treated symptomatically with anticonvulsants and surgery for tumors. Vigabatrin can be used as a first-line agent for the treatment of infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis. Medical treatment with an mTOR inhibitor everolimus may be used for treating subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, and renal angiomyolipomas. Sirolimus, another mTOR inhibitor, is approved for management of lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with a fever and right-sided swelling behind the angle of jaw. He also complains of odynophagia and difficulty moving his jaw.  He underwent a molar tooth extraction about three days ago. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is displaced medially with mild collapse of the tonsillar fossa. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a parapharyngeal abscess (anterior compartment type), an infection of the parapharyngeal space.

This space can get infected following infections of the tonsils, adenoids, and parotid glands. It can also occur following dental extractions and penetrating trauma. 

Clinically, patients may present with the following features-

  • Fever
  • Odynophagia or dysphagia
  • Trismus due to irritation of the medial pterygoid muscle
  • The collapse of the tonsillar fossa and tonsil
  • Swelling- Behind the angle of the mandible (in anterior compartment infection), parotid region or area behind the posterior pillar (in posterior compartment infection)
  • Paralysis of IX, X, XI, and XII cranial nerves is commonly seen in infections of the posterior compartment.
  • Features of internal jugular vein thrombosis and carotid artery thrombosis.

Diagnosis can be established using a CECT.

Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible, followed by blunt dissection. 

Other options:

Option B: Retropharyngeal abscess presents predominantly with features of dysphagia and difficulty breathing. Patients may also develop stridor and croupy cough. It is seen as a bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall, most typically, on one side of the midline, unlike parapharyngeal abscesses. 

Option C: Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy presents with severe pain in the throat, fever (up to 104 °F), chills and rigors, and a “hot potato voice". On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula can be pushed to the opposite side.

Option D: Lemierre’s syndrome is thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and devastating anaerobic bacteremia that follows oropharyngeal infection. It typically presents in children and young healthy adults as severe lateral neck pain and sepsis following prolonged pharyngitis.
